ANALISIS
'Desa Siluman' Bukti Basis Data Milik Pemerintah Cacat
07 Nov 2019, 07:23 by Dinda Audriene, https://www.facebook.com/CNNIndonesia


Ilustrasi desa. (CNN Indonesia/Adhi Wicaksono).

Jakarta, CNN Indonesia -- Kabar mengenai keberadaan 'desa siluman' tengah menjadi sorotan. Menteri Keuangan Sri Mulyani baru-baru ini mengungkapkan terdapat sejumlah desa yang tak berpenghuni.Ia mengklaim desa itu sengaja diciptakan untuk menyelewengkan dana desa yang sudah beberapa tahun ini disalurkan oleh pemerintah. Kabar itu baru ia dengar dari Kementerian Dalam Negeri (Kemendagri) belum lama ini. Sekretaris Jenderal Kementerian Desa, Pembangunan Daerah Tertinggal, dan Transmigrasi (Kemendes PDTT) Anwar Sanusi menuturkan pihaknya akan segera melakukan koordinasi dengan Kementerian Keuangan dan Kemendagri terkait penemuan fakta desa 'siluman' itu. Sebab, bisa jadi sebenarnya desa itu bukannya tak berpenghuni sama sekali, melainkan jumlah penduduknya yang amat sedikit. "Karena kan memang secara administratif ada ketentuan jumlah penduduk untuk sebuah desa. Nah, bisa saja jumlah penduduknya tidak memenuhi. Jadi, perlu dilihat tidak ada sama sekali atau seperti apa," ungkap Anwar kepada CNNIndonesia.com, Rabu (11/6). Sejauh ini, ia belum bisa berspekulasi mengenai keberadaan sejumlah desa yang tak berpenghuni tersebut. Anwar mengaku tidak bisa asal menyebut berapa jumlah desa yang kemungkinan jumlah penduduknya sepi atau tak berpenghuni. "Harus cek dulu lintas kementerian dulu untuk data desa," terang dia. Total desa saat ini sebanyak 74.954 wilayah. Masing-masing desa mendapatkan dana yang bervariasi dari pemerintah setiap tahunnya. "Formula perhitungannya dilihat dari kondisi desa, misalnya kemiskinan. Jadi ada desa minimal Rp800 juta, tapi juga ada yang dapat Rp2 miliar, kalau memang lebih miskin," kata Anwar. Terkait pengawasannya, ia mengatakan tidak dilakukan oleh Kemendes PDTT semata. Kemendagri dan Kemenkeu juga ikut memantau penggunaan dana desa yang dikucurkan. Ditambah, Badan Pemeriksa Keuangan (BPK), Kejaksaan Agung (Kejagung), hingga Komisi Pemberantasan Korupsi (KPK) juga ikut mengawasi aliran dana desa. Anwar menyebut akan melakukan evaluasi dengan berbagai lembaga itu terkait kejadian ini. Ekonom Universitas Indonesia (UI) Fithra Faisal mengaku tak terkejut dengan penemuan desa fiktif. Masalahnya, basis data yang dimiliki pemerintah juga masih terbatas, khususnya di daerah.


Ilustrasi desa. (CNN Indonesia/Adhi Wicaksono).

Dengan demikian, ketidakcocokkan data antara pemerintah daerah dan pemerintah pusat rentan terjadi. Pengawasan yang dilakukan pemerintah pusat pun dinilai tidak ketat. "Ini permasalahan tata kelola. Ini pekerjaan rumah pemerintah bagaimana pengawasan diperketat, basis data dibuat lebih serius," tutur Fithra. Di sisi lain, dana desa yang jumlahnya tak sedikit juga dinilai begitu menggiurkan bagi sejumlah pihak. Jangankan desa fiktif, dana desa juga tak menutup kemungkinan dimainkan oleh pejabat desa setempat. "Ini kan dana triliunan, puluhan triliunan sangat menggiurkan. Dana desa diatur aparatur desa yang secara kapasitas timpang antara pemerintah daerah dan pusat, maka bisa saja penyelewengan terjadi," imbuhnya. Andai saja basis data yang dimiliki pemerintah sudah 'apik', pastinya tak ada kucuran dana ke desa fiktif. Sebab, verifikasi yang dilakukan juga bisa dilakukan dengan benar. "Kalau sistemnya benar, harusnya ada verifikasi. Jadi, mungkin ada masalah di basis data," ujar Fithra. Diketahui, pemerintah menyediakan dana besar untuk dikucurkan ke desa. Tahun ini saja, pemerintah mengalokasikan dana desa sebesar Rp70 triliun untuk 74.954 desa. Mengutip Rancangan Anggaran Pendapatan dan Belanja Negara (APBN) 2020, dana desa tahun depan naik Rp2 triliun. Walhasil, pemerintah akan menggelontorkan Rp72 triliun untuk desa pada 2020. Jika digabung dengan transfer ke daerah, totalnya pada tahun ini sebesar Rp814,4 triliun dan 2020 mendatang Rp858,8 triliun. Ini artinya, pemerintah mengerek 5,45 persen pos belanja tersebut. Peneliti Institute for Development of Economics and Finance (INDEF) Ahmad Heri Firdaus berpendapat mengalirnya dana desa ke tempat fiktif lantaran kurangnya pengawas di masing-masing desa. Ia mensinyalir pemerintah kekurangan sumber daya manusia (SDM) agar program dana desa berjalan efektif. "Pendamping relatif sedikit, beberapa desa bisa saja hanya dipegang oleh satu pengawas," kata Ahmad. Belum lagi jika terjadi hal-hal berbau politis di lapangan. Makanya, Ahmad menganggap pemerintah perlu menambah pendamping di masing-masing daerah. Kendati begitu, penambahan pengawas bukan satu-satunya jalan. Pemerintah juga harus membenahi sistem pembagian dana desa. "Sistem integrasi dari daerah ke pusat harus benar, sistem ini bisa kembangkan jaringan lalu dibuat platform. Jadi semua data ada di situ," ucap Ahmad. Selama sistem tidak diperbaiki, maka celah untuk menyelewengkan dana desa akan selalu ada. Sekali pun jika pemerintah nantinya berhasil menindak pelaku dari pembuat desa 'siluman' ini, kalau tata kelola tak dibenahi, dana desa berpotensi terus bermasalah. "Masih ada celah, masih bisa diakalin. Harus bangun sistem yang benar," pungkasnya.(bir)

ANALYSIS
'Village of Siluman' Evidence of Government Database of Defects
Nov 7, 2019, 07:23 by Dinda Audriene, https://www.facebook.com/CNNIndonesia


Village illustration. (CNN Indonesia / Adhi Wicaksono).

Jakarta, CNN Indonesia - News about the existence of a 'stealth village' is in the spotlight. Minister of Finance Sri Mulyani recently revealed that there were a number of villages that were uninhabited. He claimed the village was intentionally created to misuse village funds that had been channeled by the government for several years. He only heard the news from the Ministry of Home Affairs (Ministry of Home Affairs) recently. Secretary General of the Ministry of Villages, Disadvantaged Regions, and Transmigration (Kemendes PDTT) Anwar Sanusi said that he would immediately coordinate with the Ministry of Finance and the Ministry of Home Affairs regarding the discovery of the 'stealth' village facts. Because, it could be that the village was not completely uninhabited, but rather a very small population. "Because there is indeed an administrative regulation on the number of residents for a village. Well, it could be that the population does not meet. So, it needs to be seen as nothing at all or what," Anwar told CNNIndonesia.com, Wednesday (11/6). So far, he has not been able to speculate about the existence of a number of uninhabited villages. Anwar claimed that he could not just mention the number of villages that were likely to be deserted or uninhabited. "You have to check cross-ministry first for village data," he explained. The total village is currently 74,954 territories. Each village receives funding that varies from the government each year. "The calculation formula is seen from the condition of the village, for example poverty. So there is a village of at least Rp800 million, but there are also those who can be Rp2 billion, if it is poorer," Anwar said. Regarding his supervision, he said that it was not carried out by the PDTT Ministry of Health alone. The Ministry of Home Affairs and the Ministry of Finance also monitored the use of village funds disbursed. Plus, the Supreme Audit Agency (BPK), the Attorney General's Office (AGO), and the Corruption Eradication Commission (KPK) also monitor the flow of village funds. Anwar said he would conduct evaluations with various institutions related to this incident. Economist at the University of Indonesia (UI) Fithra Faisal said he was not surprised by the discovery of a fictitious village. The problem is that the government-owned database is still limited, especially in the regions.


Village illustration. (CNN Indonesia / Adhi Wicaksono).

Thus, data mismatch between local and central government is vulnerable. Supervision conducted by the central government was considered not strict. "This is a matter of governance. This is the homework of the government, how monitoring is tightened, the database is made more serious," said Fithra. On the other hand, the amount of village funds which is not insignificant is also considered so tempting for a number of parties. Never mind fictitious villages, village funds also did not rule out the possibility of being played by local village officials. "This is trillions of funds, tens of trillions are very lucrative. Village funds are regulated by village apparatuses, which have an imbalanced capacity between the regional and central governments, so fraud can occur," he added. If only the database owned by the government was 'neat', surely there would be no funding to fictitious villages. Therefore, verification can also be done correctly. "If the system is correct, there should be verification. So, there might be a problem in the database," said Fithra. It is known, the government provides large funds to be disbursed to the village. This year alone, the government allocated IDR 70 trillion in village funds for 74,954 villages. Citing the 2020 State Budget and Expenditure (APBN), village funds will increase by Rp2 trillion next year. As a result, the government will pour Rp72 trillion for villages in 2020. If combined with transfers to the regions, the total this year will be Rp814.4 trillion and in 2020 Rp858.8 trillion will come. This means, the government hoisted 5.45 percent of the shopping post. Institute for Development of Economics and Finance (INDEF) researcher Ahmad Heri Firdaus believes that the flow of village funds to fictitious places is due to the lack of supervisors in each village. He indicated the government lacked human resources (HR) so that the village funding program would run effectively. "Relatives are relatively few, some villages may only be held by one supervisor," Ahmad said. Not to mention if things happen politically in the field. Hence, Ahmad considers the government needs to add assistants in each region. Even so, the addition of supervisors is not the only way. The government must also improve the system of distribution of village funds. "The integration system from the region to the center must be correct, this system can develop a network and then make a platform. So all the data is there," Ahmad said. As long as the system is not repaired, there will always be a gap to misuse village funds. Even if the government succeeded in cracking down on the perpetrators of this 'stealth' village maker, if governance was not addressed, village funds would potentially continue to be problematic. "There are still gaps, can still be copied. Must build the right system," he concluded. (Beer)
